title: 110_hr2871
content: The "Payday Loan Reform Act of 2007" prohibits payday loans based on checks drawn on or authorized withdrawals from depository institutions. Section 128 of the Truth in Lending Act prohibits payday loans if the creditor knows the check is drawn on a depository institution or the account to be debited is at a depository institution. The term 'payday loan' refers to a short-term cash advance given to a consumer in exchange for their personal check or authorization to debit their account, with deferred presentation or negotiation until a future date. The consumer's account will be debited for the advance amount plus a fee on a designated future date. PROHIBITION ON INSURED DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS MAKING PAYDAY LOANS. Section 18 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act prohibits insured depository institutions from making payday loans, defined as short-term cash advances in exchange for a personal check or share draft plus a fee. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act prohibits insured depository institutions from making payday loans, which are short-term cash advances in exchange for a personal check or share draft plus a fee, where the consumer authorizes the institution to debit their account on a future date. SEC. 4. PENALTIES AND REMEDIES. Any credit agreement, promissory note, or contract prohibited by this Act is void. Creditors violating section 128(e) are liable under specified paragraphs. Remedies provided by this Act are additional and do not limit other available legal remedies. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will be effective 30 days after enactment and will apply to all new loans and renewals made after that date.
